description:
Physcomitrium patens is a small, acrocarpous moss species belonging to the family Funariaceae. It is commonly known as the common beaked moss or spreading Physcomitrium.

This species is widely distributed across Europe, Asia, and North America, typically found growing on soil, often in disturbed or exposed areas such as roadsides, banks, and bare ground.

Physcomitrium patens has a delicate, green gametophyte (the dominant phase in the moss life cycle) that forms low, cushion-like tufts or mats. The leaves are oblong-lanceolate in shape and can have a distinct, short, apiculate tip. The capsules (sporophytes) are erect, cylindrical, and often have a distinct "beak" at the tip, which is a characteristic feature of this species.

The species reproduces both sexually, through the production of spores within the capsules, and asexually, through the fragmentation of the gametophyte. Physcomitrium patens is considered a pioneer species, often being one of the first mosses to colonize newly exposed or disturbed soil habitats.
